node.title: SA records 13 new COVID-19 cases as government works to fast-track Omicron testing
node.alt: SA Premier Steven Marshall speaking at Flinders University
node.description: South Australia recordsÂ another 13 cases of COVID-19, with the majority expected to be the Delta variant.
node.content:
["South Australia has recorded another 13 cases of COVID-19.", "The figure was revealed by\u00a0Premier Steven Marshall during a press conference on a different topic.\u00a0", "Mr Marshall told reporters the \"vast majority\" of the new cases were the Delta variant of the virus.", "\"I think our state should now be ready to have these types of numbers pretty much on a daily basis as we go into this next phase on the disease,\" Mr Marshall said.\u00a0", "Mr Marshall said testing to determine if a COVID-positive person has the Omicron variant would become faster later in the week.\u00a0", "\"We still have this wait time to get confirmation of Omicron, that, by the end of the week, will be almost instantaneous but at the moment it is taking two or three days to get that confirmation as we do that genome sequencing,\" he said.\u00a0", "\"I understand that this is fast-tracked with a new arrangement that will be in place later this week.\"", "Yesterday SA Health confirmed two cases of COVID-19 recorded in the state last week are the Omicron variant.", "Any close contacts of the Omicron cases have been ordered to quarantine for 14 days \u2014 regardless of their vaccination status \u2014 instead of the usual seven days.", "However, the state government has since announced it is reviewing whether the requirement can be reduced back to seven days.", "", "
Why we hear about some COVID-19 variants more than others
"]
